channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: If History Is a Guide, Crimeans’ Celebration May Be Short-Lived
item.description: South Ossetia had high hopes when Russia took control of the enclave from Georgia in 2008, but its economy is stagnant and corruption is rife.
item.dc:creator: By OLESYA VARTANYAN and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Justyna Mielnikiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Youths waited for a bus in Atotsi, Georgia, near the border with South Ossetia, where men in unmarked military uniforms recently started building a border fence.

item.title: Malaysia Turns to F.B.I. for Help in Plane Inquiry
item.description: The authorities said they were trying to recover data deleted from a flight simulator custom-built by the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: A relative of a passenger on the lost flight cried while speaking with members of the news media on Wednesday at Kuala Lumpur International Airport.

item.title: Russians and Militias Seize Ukrainian Naval Headquarters
item.description: There were no reports of injuries as officers of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet took over the Ukrainian Navy installation in Sevastopol, Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A Ukrainian naval officer passed by Russian military personnel as he left the Ukrainian naval headquarters in Sevastopol on Wednesday after Russian forces and local militiamen seized control of the facility.

item.title: Report Faults South African Leader on State-Funded Home Improvements
item.description: The public prosecutor accused President Jacob G. Zuma of “unduly” benefiting from improvements to his private estate that were made in the name of security.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: One Year Later, Dead Pigs Discovered in Another Chinese River
item.description: On Wednesday, officials in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province, said that more than 100 dead pigs had been pulled from the Gan River.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A photograph taken on Tuesday shows a dead pig pulled from the Gan River in Nanchang, Jiangxi Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Insurers Seek to Capitalize on China’s Smog
item.description: Financial institutions are finding opportunities amid China’s recently announced “war against pollution,” with insurers offering payouts to travelers and residents on pollution-choked days.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: Smog engulfs a view of the Oriental Pearl TV Tower in the Pudong financial district in Shanghai.

item.title: Lisbon Journal: Student Deaths Spark Debate Over Hazing at Portugal’s Universities
item.description: Some credit the ritual with building esprit de corps among students, while others say it has grown increasingly dangerous.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Francisco Seco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lusófona University students who support hazing attended an event in February for the six students who drowned in December.

item.title: Swiss Begin to Count Cost of Immigration Limits
item.description: The vote to clamp down on foreign workers has put the country at loggerheads with Europe and has alarmed its multinational business community.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY

item.title: What Pakistan Knew About Bin Laden
item.description: Our supposed ally had a special desk devoted to managing Osama bin Laden. How can the U.S. fight extremism when we’re unable to confront it where it really lives?
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Alex Majoli/, for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban recruits in 2008 in Quetta, Pakistan, where leading organizers of the Afghan insurgency are based.

item.title: India Ink: Notable Absences in Congress Party’s Latest Slate of Candidates
item.description: The party has yet to name someone for the increasingly high-profile parliamentary race in Varanasi, where the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi, will be contesting.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Activist’s Death Questioned as U.N. Considers Chinese Rights Report
item.description: Five days after Cao Shunli, an activist who called for greater public participation in the United Nations human rights process, died in detention, the Chinese government’s rights report was expected to be adopted by the United Nations in Geneva.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Cao Shunli, photographed in March 2013, died last Friday while in custody.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Opponents of China Trade Deal Occupy Taiwan’s Legislature
item.description: Protesters said the trade act would “forfeit Taiwan’s future” and accused President Ma Ying-jeou of forcing through the measure without allowing a review of its details.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Banners criticizing President Ma Ying-jeou went up during the occupation of the legislature, which began Tuesday night.

item.title: Israel Attacks Syrian Positions in Golan Heights
item.description: Airstrikes along the cease-fire line appeared to be the sharpest exchange since the civil war in Syria broke out three years ago.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: An Israeli officer with one of the soldiers wounded on Tuesday by an explosion along the Israeli-Syrian cease-fire line.

item.title: India Ink: A Village Brings Down Its Hills as Lure of Mining Grows
item.description: So much money can be made from limestone in Nongtalang, in the northeastern state of Meghalaya, that the few who voice concern about the environment feel like outcasts.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Alldrina Nonglamin, 40, a mine owner in Nongtalang in the Jaintia Hills of Meghalaya.

item.title: Politics Won’t Be on First Lady’s China Itinerary, Aides Say
item.description: The White House is billing Michelle Obama’s visit as a cultural exchange, but political overtones will be almost impossible to avoid.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID S. JOACHIM
item.media:description: Michelle Obama at Yu Ying, a Washington charter school.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New U.S. Ambassador to China Gets a Fast Start
item.description: The new American ambassador to China, Max Baucus, visited the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Tuesday morning to present a copy of his credentials, a formality that allowed him to meet with journalists at the United States Embassy in the afternoon.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Ambassador Max Baucus briefed journalists on Tuesday at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing.

item.title: The Lede: Video of Putin’s Complete Speech on Crimea
item.description: President Vladimir Putin’s address welcoming Crimea to the Russian Federation, and a subsequent signing ceremony, were broadcast with simultaneous English translation by RT, the Kremlin-funded network.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Briefing: France: Greenpeace Activists Arrested in Break-In
item.description: The police arrested 57 activists who used a truck on Tuesday to break through two security barriers and ram their way into a nuclear power plant in eastern France, the organization said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Guatemala: Ex-President Admits Taking Taiwan Bribes
item.description: Former President Alfonso Portillo pleaded guilty Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to a charge that he accepted bribes in exchange for diplomatic recognition of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Leaked File Details U.S. Phone Monitoring Abroad
item.description: The National Security Agency is recording all phone calls and their routing data in one foreign country and retaining that data for a month so that it can be analyzed, according to a report based on a document leaked by Edward J. Snowden.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GLANZ

item.title: News Analysis: If Not a Cold War, a Return to a Chilly Rivalry
item.description: Tensions over Crimea may not bring a new Cold War, but analysts worry about a long period of confrontation and alienation.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Putin Reclaims Crimea for Russia and Bitterly Denounces the West
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he was reversing what he described as a historical mistake, declaring, “Crimea has always been an integral part of Russia in the hearts and minds of people.”
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Women outside Simferopol, Ukraine watched an address by President Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday.

item.title: News Analysis: Russian Aggression Puts NATO in Spotlight
item.description: Russia’s moves in Ukraine have revived the North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s role as a counterweight to Moscow, even as it wrestles with its response.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland, a NATO member state, in Warsaw on Tuesday.

item.title: A Divide Among Palestinians on a Two-State Solution
item.description: A son of President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority is among those younger people expressing support for the creation of a single state.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If you don’t want to give me independence, at least give me civil rights,” says Tareq Abbas, 48, a son of the Palestinian Authority president.

item.title: Russia’s Most-Wanted Rebel Is Dead, Website Says
item.description: The site, which represents militant groups in southern Russia, did not say how or when Doku Umarov, a Chechen rebel leader, had died.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Doku Umarov, who released a video clip last summer in which he threatened to attack the Sochi Olympics.
